subject: Change the word TS to Time Stamp & add time unit
commitMessage:
Change the word TS to Time Stamp & add time unit

 - The Message argument in the BIOSPOSTCode Message Entry
   uses short form wording for TS (Time Stamp) & without any time unit.

 - As the Message argument is directly displayed on OpenBMC GUI
   as it is, word "TS" would create customer confusion due to it
   not being a well known acronym. Also a field like this that
   captures a physical quantity(time) should have units.

 - Redfish clients should not be parsing the message argument, so
   changing this wording should not break them.

 - Also, this commit changes ":" to ";" in the Message argument to
   makes things look consistent.

 - As we changed the content of Message in the Message Entry, we had to
   bump up the minor version of the Message registry.

Tested By:

1. Redfish Validator Passed.

Signed-off-by: Manojkiran Eda <manojkiran.eda@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I17924c2dfdcf34563f8f8cd325011e13cb70e476

Patch Set 5:

This patchset looks ok, but suffers from a core problem in that we can't be changing the message registry without updating the version number, and the version numbers have been baked into the code all over the place instead of just being here.  Until that problem is solved, we can't really make any changes to the OpenBMC message registry.

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> This patchset looks ok, but suffers from a core problem in that we can't be changing the message registry without updating the version number, and the version numbers have been baked into the code all over the place instead of just being here.  Until that problem is solved, we can't really make any changes to the OpenBMC message registry.

Redfish bumps the errata version of the registry when correcting messages (1.8.0 -> 1.8.1). Redfish bumps the minor version when adding new messages. (1.8.0 -> 1.9.0). 
Should we also be bumping the minor version when adding new messages ? If so, then we should also hold off adding new messages to the registry.

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> > Patch Set 5:
> > 
> > This patchset looks ok, but suffers from a core problem in that we can't be changing the message registry without updating the version number, and the version numbers have been baked into the code all over the place instead of just being here.  Until that problem is solved, we can't really make any changes to the OpenBMC message registry.
> 
> Redfish bumps the errata version of the registry when correcting messages (1.8.0 -> 1.8.1). Redfish bumps the minor version when adding new messages. (1.8.0 -> 1.9.0). 
> Should we also be bumping the minor version when adding new messages ? If so, then we should also hold off adding new messages to the registry.

I did a brief investigation of the impact of registry version on our logging.  What I found is that log_services.hpp, message_registries::getMessage currently ignores the version fields.  So, it looks like we may be safe to start increasing the registry version number to track new messages without impacting the existing logging.  There is a larger discussion still around when and how to version and how to handle it correctly in log_services.hpp, but for now, we may not be blocked.  As a test, I changed the registry version to 0.2 and my Redfish log continued to work correctly even though my events were logged as 0.1.

The larger discussion may be better on the mailing list or Discord.  If you'd like, and we're ready for that discussion, I could start something.

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> > Patch Set 5:
> > 
> > > Patch Set 5:
> > > 
> > > This patchset looks ok, but suffers from a core problem in that we can't be changing the message registry without updating the version number, and the version numbers have been baked into the code all over the place instead of just being here.  Until that problem is solved, we can't really make any changes to the OpenBMC message registry.
> > 
> > Redfish bumps the errata version of the registry when correcting messages (1.8.0 -> 1.8.1). Redfish bumps the minor version when adding new messages. (1.8.0 -> 1.9.0). 

Sounds fine to me.  The biggest thing for me is that the version numbers are different and incrementing.  For all I care they could be A, B, C, D.  With that said, lets do what Gunnar suggested and what Redfish does.

> > Should we also be bumping the minor version when adding new messages ? If so, then we should also hold off adding new messages to the registry.
> 
> I did a brief investigation of the impact of registry version on our logging.  What I found is that log_services.hpp, message_registries::getMessage currently ignores the version fields.  So, it looks like we may be safe to start increasing the registry version number to track new messages without impacting the existing logging.  There is a larger discussion still around when and how to version and how to handle it correctly in log_services.hpp, but for now, we may not be blocked.  As a test, I changed the registry version to 0.2 and my Redfish log continued to work correctly even though my events were logged as 0.1.

Sweet.  That's way better than I though the situation was.

> 
> The larger discussion may be better on the mailing list or Discord.  If you'd like, and we're ready for that discussion, I could start something.





For the context of this patch, lets just get the version number reved, then this should be good to go.

Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)

Oops, forgot to send this earlier...

I see 205 definitions of TS and time stamp isn't even one of them.  
https://acronyms.thefreedictionary.com/TS
Clients should not be parsing the message, so should not break them.
I agree, but this should be mentioned in the commit message.
Was this a mistake?  I don't see it called out in the commit message.  It does make things consistent, so I approve of this change.
Nit, technically this is the OpenBMC message registry, and the BiosPostCode message id.
Ack
weird spacing?
Done
More details needed here.  I agree with you, but seeing as how someone wrote this code initially, clearly there's some dissent, so lets get the position written clearly.
I added details as much as possible, can you tell what else exactly you are looking for ? i can add that as well.

I'm looking for details on why this would cause customer confusion.  is it because it's short?  Is it because it's abbreviated?  Is it because it uses capital letters?  Is it because T doesn't render into certain languages?



Ideally, the next time someone tries to check in an abbreviation, I'd like to be able to point to this commit and say "no, some took issues with that in the past, and here's why"
Understood, thanks for explaining. Updated the commit message.

Thank you, Manoj for updating the commit. This change came from testing with users that were asking what is TS offset. When it was explained, the next question was what the format was, is it seconds?

This is the why behind the change. i think the commit message is clear about user confusion, I just wanted to share a little more detail.
I thought the units (I believe seconds) for the Time Stamp Offset were also to be added.
sure , added the time unit as well.
Ack

Nit.  This makes it sound like the GUI team would cause customer confusion, which, while not always untrue, I'm assuming isn't what you meant in this case.

Still needs "why" this would be confusing.
wording?
Done
Bonus points to whoever adds this to the registry (unless I am missing it)
Not sure how this got sneaked in, I did not find this TestEventLog in the openbmc message registry.

For what it's worth, a quick peruse of the specification shows that the SubmitTestEvent endpoint was implemented completely not to spec.  This structure should be coming from the EventId, EventTimestamp, EventTimestamp, and other parameters from the users request, not hardcoded to something non-existent here.

Appu, you show up on the blame for this.  Could you please take a look at implementing this to the spec?

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/9a128eb3fc3008f802974360e98de6495ed1a66b/static/redfish/v1/schema/EventService_v1.xml#L89

Is the fields that this should be pulling from, and what should be decoded in SubmitTestEvent.  I'm really surprised this didn't show up in any testing.  Having all this stuff hardcoded makes this endpoint kinda useless.
To be clear, "blame" means "git blame", not that I literally blame you for this.
For consistency I wish this had an 3 digits too.

Sure, this needs a fix in the getMessage() function, as it was not coded to parse a message registry number which is A.B.C.D.E, so it was failing the validator.

Fixed it in the latest patch, the validator is passed now.
Thanks for fixing!

Sorry if I lead you astray here.
Would like consistency across our Messages.
why loose the digit?
Ack

This is not how MessageId is specified:
https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0266_1.12.1.pdf
11.5.10.2 MessageId format
The MessageId property value shall be in the format:
<RegistryName>.<MajorVersion>.<MinorVersion>.<MessageKey>

Then all our MessageIds are wrong
E.g. 
      "MessageId": "Base.1.8.1.PropertyValueFormatError",
And I feel this rule conflicts with Redfish's registries.

https://redfish.dmtf.org/registries/Base.1.9.0.json
Sure, reverted this change back to how it was.
Yes, this seems like a conflict between the Redfish spec and the Base registry.  It may be good to get clarification from the DMTF on the correct format.

I think this change will break anyone using the current format without the SubMinorVersion.  It would be good to make this change in a backward-compatible way and give time for all existing Redfish messages to be updated.
It should also be noted, this code is unsafe as written.  We need to be range checking the resulting vector of version pieces.  Please add that as part of your commit.
Sure, I have changed it back to how it was earlier and just incremented the Minor version alone .

For what it's worth, this shouldn't be here.  This file is for the base registry, and this implies that we're using custom registries as return codes, which I don't think we're allowed to do.

Not an issue with this patchset, but something to fix.
